Employment Composition Signal

Employment composition signal: tracking shifts across key sectors and categories in the labour market.

As of 2026-01-01

Gemini Summary

Signal Summary:

  • The Employment Composition signal (1) indicates a Neutral regime in the labor market as of 2025-11-01, following a brief shift to Cool (slack rising) in July-August 2025. This suggests a period of relative stability but with underlying components near the threshold for increasing slack.
  • Conviction Band: Medium | Interpretation Confidence: High Confidence | Internal Conflict Flag: No.

Key Dynamics:

  • The `Employment_Composition_Smoothed` z-score recovered slightly to -0.671993 as of 2025-11-01, moving away from the -0.75 Cool threshold, after dipping to -0.794936 in July 2025.
  • The unemployment rate increased to 4.6% in November 2025, while the `emp_pop_ratio` declined slightly to 59.6% and the `participation_rate` steadied at 62.5%.
  • Conditional Invalidation: A sustained decline of the `Employment_Composition_Smoothed` z-score below -0.75 would definitively signal a shift to a "COOL (slack rising)" regime.

Scenario Balance:

  • Base Case dominant: The labor market composition remains Neutral, with conditions near the edge of slackening.
  • Upside secondary: Improved participation and employment-population ratios, combined with a decline in the unemployment rate, could strengthen the Neutral reading or move towards Hot.
  • Downside plausible: A further rise in unemployment and continued softening in participation/employment-population ratios would lead to a confirmed "COOL (slack rising)" regime.

Time Horizon & Aggregation:

  • Time Horizon: Cyclical (months) – labor market composition changes tend to unfold over several months.
  • Aggregation Weight Hint: Medium – this signal provides a foundational view of labor market health, but should be cross-referenced with other labor and inflation indicators.

Macro Relevance:

  • This signal primarily informs the macro dimension of slack, providing insight into the overall health and tightness of the labor market.
  • It currently suggests a mid-to-late cycle position, where labor market conditions are either stable at lower levels of tightness or beginning to show signs of softening.
  • It typically interacts with wage growth signals (2), labor market tightness (3), and inflation signals (4) to confirm broader macro trends.

Data & References:

  • BLS (LNS11300000) Labor force participation rate: 62.5% (2025-11-01).
  • BLS (LNS12300000) Employment-population ratio: 59.6% (2025-11-01).
  • BLS (LNS14000000) Unemployment rate: 4.6% (2025-11-01).
  • Datapoints most influential for the current state are the `Employment_Composition_Smoothed` z-score and the individual z-scores of participation, employment-population ratio, and unemployment.
  • Additional public datasets that would improve depth or reliability include the Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) data and Average Hourly Earnings.
